sandypython.utils¶

class sandypython.utils.DeactivateSandbox[source]¶

Context manager which will call sandypython.core.end_sandbox() if the sandbox was started, then sandypython.core.start_sandbox() if it ended it. It is save to use this without activating the sandbox before hand (it will be a no-op).

Example:

with utils.DeactivateSandbox:
    open("f.txt")
    import sys
class sandypython.utils.ActivateSandbox[source]¶

Context manager which will call sandypython.core.start_sandbox() if the sandbox has not been started, then sandypython.core.end_sandbox() if it started it. It is save to use this with the sandbox already started (it will be a no-op).

Example:

with utils.ActivateSandbox:
    core.exec_str(bad_code)
sandypython.utils.check_builtins(func)[source]¶

A decorator to make sure sandypython.core.detamper_builtins() is called before any function code

sandypython.utils.type_checker(**kwargs)[source]¶

Checks the types of all arguments against what is expected, and raises TypeError if they do not. It can be used to ensure no malicious types can enter a function that lifts the sandbox. It takes the types in kwarg form. A tuple of types means that the args can be any of those in the tuple. Any can be used to indicate any type.

Example:

@type_checker(self=Any, a=(int, dict, None), b=str, c=str)
def f(self, a, b, c=""):
    return str(a) + b + c
sandypython.utils.type_checker_annotated(func)[source]¶

Same usage as type_checker(), but takes the types in annotation form.

Example:

@type_checker_annotated
def f_ann(self: Any, a: (int, dict, list, None), b: str, c: str=""):
    return str(a) + b + c
class sandypython.utils.Any[source]¶

Placeholder class used by type_checker() and type_checker_annotated() to represent any type.

sandypython.utils.checked_importer(imp_filter, noise=False)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • imp_filter (function) – function that should take the name of the module to import, the path of the code importing the module and the path to the module, and return a boolean indicating whether the import is allowed or not
  • noise (bool) – enables extra logging info

Importer that can be used to replace __import__.

Example:

core.replace_builtin("__import__", utils.checked_importer(imp_filter))
sandypython.utils.import_filter_by_name(allowed_map)[source]¶

Filter for checked_importer() which takes a dict of paths against allowed names. The “default” key represents the modules all code can import.

Example:

imp_map = {os.path.abspath("./badcode/*.py"): ["./badcode/*.py"],
           "default": ["sys"]}
i = import_filter_by_name(imp_map)
i("sys", "random place", "doesn't matter")  # True
i("a_mod", "random place", "doesn't matter")  # False
i("a_mod", "./badcode/a_mod_importer.py", "doesn't matter")  # True
sandypython.utils.import_filter_by_path(allowed_map)[source]¶

Filter for checked_importer() which takes a dict of paths against allowed import paths. The “default” key represents the modules all code can import.

Example:

imp_map = {os.path.abspath("./*.py"): ["/*.py"],
           "default": ["./*.py"]}
i = import_filter_by_path(imp_map)
i("sys", "random place", "/usr/lib/python3.4/sys.py")  # False
i("a_mod", "random place", "./a_mod.py")  # True
i("a_mod", "./a_mod_importer.py", "/usr/lib/python3.4/sys.py")  # True
